texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: author: Major Hayden date: '2025-02-16' A recent switch back to i3 (from sway) left me wondering how to examine just the Xorg logs sent to journald. tags:
texts.text: author: Major Hayden date: '2025-02-16' A recent switch back to i3 (from sway) left me wondering how to examine just the Xorg logs sent to journald. tags:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: i3
texts.text: i3

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: fedora
texts.text: fedora

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: linux
texts.text: linux

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I love being an early adopter and trudging off into the unknown. After all, that's one of the best ways to learn new things and you end up improving the experience for everyone who comes behind you. However, things can get a little frustrating from time to time especially when your daily work dictates that your desktop works really well. 😉
texts.text: I love being an early adopter and trudging off into the unknown. After all, that's one of the best ways to learn new things and you end up improving the experience for everyone who comes behind you. However, things can get a little frustrating from time to time especially when your daily work dictates that your desktop works really well. 😉

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sway has been my desktop of choice for a few years and although it seems to work well, I ran into lots of issues with Wayland. It was easy to plot a course around most of these problems, but not all of them.
texts.text: Sway has been my desktop of choice for a few years and although it seems to work well, I ran into lots of issues with Wayland. It was easy to plot a course around most of these problems, but not all of them.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've recently run back to safety with my old, trusty, i3 window manager in Xorg. Then I realized a few of my Xorg configuration weren't taking effect and I couldn't figure out how to isolate the Xorg logs in the system journal to narrow down the problem.
texts.text: I've recently run back to safety with my old, trusty, i3 window manager in Xorg. Then I realized a few of my Xorg configuration weren't taking effect and I couldn't figure out how to isolate the Xorg logs in the system journal to narrow down the problem.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Skip to the end if you're short on time or peruse the next section if you haven't been deep in the innards of your system journal in a while. 🔍
texts.text: Skip to the end if you're short on time or peruse the next section if you haven't been deep in the innards of your system journal in a while. 🔍

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Journal metadata
texts.text: Journal metadata

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every journal entry in journald has metadata attached to it which you can use to filter the logs. Most people know about filtering based on systemd services, like this:
texts.text: Every journal entry in journald has metadata attached to it which you can use to filter the logs. Most people know about filtering based on systemd services, like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
> journalctl --boot --unit chronyd.service | head
systemd[1]: Starting chronyd.service - NTP client/server...
chronyd[2662]: chronyd version 4.6.1 starting (+CMDMON +NTP +REFCLOCK +RTC +PRIVDROP +SCFILTER +SIGND +ASYNCDNS +NTS +SECHASH +IPV6 +DEBUG)
chronyd[2662]: Using leap second list /usr/share/zoneinfo/leap-seconds.list
chronyd[2662]: Frequency -3.595 +/- 6.086 ppm read from /var/lib/chrony/drift
chronyd[2662]: Loaded seccomp filter (level 2)
systemd[1]: Started chronyd.service - NTP client/server.
chronyd[2662]: Added source 192.168.10.1
chronyd[2662]: Selected source 208.67.72.50 (2.fedora.pool.ntp.org)
chronyd[2662]: System clock TAI offset set to 37 seconds
chronyd[2662]: Selected source 173.73.96.68 (2.fedora.pool.ntp.org)
texts.text:
> journalctl --boot --unit chronyd.service | head
systemd[1]: Starting chronyd.service - NTP client/server...
chronyd[2662]: chronyd version 4.6.1 starting (+CMDMON +NTP +REFCLOCK +RTC +PRIVDROP +SCFILTER +SIGND +ASYNCDNS +NTS +SECHASH +IPV6 +DEBUG)
chronyd[2662]: Using leap second list /usr/share/zoneinfo/leap-seconds.list
chronyd[2662]: Frequency -3.595 +/- 6.086 ppm read from /var/lib/chrony/drift
chronyd[2662]: Loaded seccomp filter (level 2)
systemd[1]: Started chronyd.service - NTP client/server.
chronyd[2662]: Added source 192.168.10.1
chronyd[2662]: Selected source 208.67.72.50 (2.fedora.pool.ntp.org)
chronyd[2662]: System clock TAI offset set to 37 seconds
chronyd[2662]: Selected source 173.73.96.68 (2.fedora.pool.ntp.org)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This command shows all of the messages from the
texts.text: This command shows all of the messages from the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: chronyd
texts.text: chronyd

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: service since the last boot. However, we can get much more specific with our filtering using other criteria.
texts.text: service since the last boot. However, we can get much more specific with our filtering using other criteria.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Examining metadata
texts.text: Examining metadata

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can examine the metadata behind each log line with the json output in journalctl:
texts.text: You can examine the metadata behind each log line with the json output in journalctl:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
> journalctl --boot --unit chronyd.service -o json -n 1 | jq
{
  "_CMDLINE": "/usr/sbin/chronyd -F 2",
  "_SYSTEMD_CGROUP": "/system.slice/chronyd.service",
  "_MACHINE_ID": "xxxxx",
  "_UID": "990",
  "SYSLOG_TIMESTAMP": "Feb 16 13:55:59 ",
  "__SEQNUM_ID": "c94633ee6da2480ca4602ca6ab47f82a",
  "_PID": "2662",
  "PRIORITY": "6",
  "_HOSTNAME": "zorro",
  "_SYSTEMD_SLICE": "system.slice",
  "SYSLOG_FACILITY": "3",
  "_GID": "989",
  "_SYSTEMD_INVOCATION_ID": "156fce8836374564b01aeb6628160ccb",
  "__CURSOR": "s=c94633ee6da2480ca4602ca6ab47f82a;i=19fb3a;b=ed9e1fccb1744136a3d726bbf2425388;m=33abfdf67;t=62e47cbf2b72f;x=f9a8d4e3bc4fef30",
  "__MONOTONIC_TIMESTAMP": "13870554983",
  "_SOURCE_REALTIME_TIMESTAMP": "1739735759501027",
  "_TRANSPORT": "syslog",
  "_EXE": "/usr/sbin/chronyd",
  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT": "chronyd.service",
  "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER": "chronyd",
  "_BOOT_ID": "ed9e1fccb1744136a3d726bbf2425388",
  "__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP": "1739735759501103",
  "__SEQNUM": "1702714",
  "_RUNTIME_SCOPE": "system",
  "SYSLOG_PID": "2662",
  "_CAP_EFFECTIVE": "2000400",
  "MESSAGE": "Selected source 173.73.96.68 (2.fedora.pool.ntp.org)",
  "_COMM": "chronyd",
  "_SELINUX_CONTEXT": "system_u:system_r:chronyd_t:s0"
}
texts.text:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The most helpful one for us is
texts.text: The most helpful one for us is

texts.label: code
texts.orig: _COMM_
texts.text: _COMM_

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . We can use it to limit our search solely to Xorg logs.
texts.text: . We can use it to limit our search solely to Xorg logs.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Every Xorg startup has a line with the Xorg version that looks like this:
texts.text: Every Xorg startup has a line with the Xorg version that looks like this:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: X.Org X Server 1.21.1.15
texts.text: X.Org X Server 1.21.1.15

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . Let's search for that:
texts.text: . Let's search for that:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
> journalctl --boot -o json | grep -i "x.org x server" | jq
{
  "_HOSTNAME": "zorro",
  "_BOOT_ID": "ed9e1fccb1744136a3d726bbf2425388",
  "_SYSTEMD_INVOCATION_ID": "5cf933063b1246909d4ea15e7154bff4",
  "_MACHINE_ID": "xxxxx",
  "__CURSOR": "s=c94633ee6da2480ca4602ca6ab47f82a;i=19de06;b=ed9e1fccb1744136a3d726bbf2425388;m=4597347;t=62e2f4fcc855d;x=b4f482006e1523ff",
  "__MONOTONIC_TIMESTAMP": "72971079",
  "_SYSTEMD_SESSION": "2",
  "_SYSTEMD_SLICE": "user-1000.slice",
  "_SELINUX_CONTEXT": "system_u:system_r:xdm_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023",
  "__SEQNUM_ID": "c94633ee6da2480ca4602ca6ab47f82a",
  "_AUDIT_LOGINUID": "1000",
  "__REALTIME_TIMESTAMP": "1739630597408093",
  "_CMDLINE": "/usr/libexec/Xorg vt2 -displayfd 3 -auth /run/user/1000/gdm/Xauthority -nolisten tcp -background none -noreset -keeptty -novtswitch -verbose 3",
  "_AUDIT_SESSION": "2",
  "_SYSTEMD_USER_SLICE": "-.slice",
  "__SEQNUM": "1695238",
  "_GID": "1000",
  "_RUNTIME_SCOPE": "system",
  "SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER": "/usr/libexec/gdm-x-session",
  "MESSAGE": "X.Org X Server 1.21.1.15",
  "_STREAM_ID": "7f35e3ce14d44dc8b589be76d4d355d9",
  "_TRANSPORT": "stdout",
  "_CAP_EFFECTIVE": "0",
  "_SYSTEMD_UNIT": "session-2.scope",
  "_UID": "1000",
  "_EXE": "/usr/libexec/Xorg",
  "PRIORITY": "4",
  "_COMM": "Xorg",
  "_SYSTEMD_CGROUP": "/user.slice/user-1000.slice/session-2.scope",
  "_SYSTEMD_OWNER_UID": "1000",
  "_PID": "3929"
}

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Note that the value for
texts.text: Note that the value for

texts.label: code

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: is
texts.text: is

texts.label: code
texts.orig: Xorg
texts.text: Xorg

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: . We can use that to search our logs with ease using the
texts.text: . We can use that to search our logs with ease using the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: cat
texts.text: cat

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: output from journalctl, which makes the output as terse as possible. It removes all the headers and make it look like you're reading a plain old text log file:
texts.text: output from journalctl, which makes the output as terse as possible. It removes all the headers and make it look like you're reading a plain old text log file:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
> journalctl --output cat --boot _COMM=Xorg | head
(--) Log file renamed from "/home/major/.local/share/xorg/Xorg.pid-3929.log" to "/home/major/.local/share/xorg/Xorg.0.log"
X.Org X Server 1.21.1.15
X Protocol Version 11, Revision 0
Current Operating System: Linux zorro 6.12.13-200.fc41.x86_64 #1 SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Sat Feb  8 20:05:26 UTC 2025 x86_64

	to make sure that you have the latest version.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: In my particular case, I was missing the amdgpu driver for Xorg. I installed the
texts.text: In my particular case, I was missing the amdgpu driver for Xorg. I installed the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: xorg-x11-drv-amdgpu
texts.text: xorg-x11-drv-amdgpu

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: package, rebooted, and now my logs showed the driver being loaded on startup:
texts.text: package, rebooted, and now my logs showed the driver being loaded on startup:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
> journalctl --output cat --boot _COMM=Xorg | grep -i amdgpu | head
(II) Applying OutputClass "AMDgpu" to /dev/dri/card1
	loading driver: amdgpu
(==) Matched amdgpu as autoconfigured driver 0
(II) LoadModule: "amdgpu"
(II) Loading /usr/lib64/xorg/modules/drivers/amdgpu_drv.so
(II) Module amdgpu: vendor="X.Org Foundation"
(II) AMDGPU: Driver for AMD Radeon:
	All GPUs supported by the amdgpu kernel driver
(II) AMDGPU(0): Creating default Display subsection in Screen section
(==) AMDGPU(0): Depth 24, (--) framebuffer bpp 32
texts.text:
> journalctl --output cat --boot _COMM=Xorg | grep -i amdgpu | head
(II) Applying OutputClass "AMDgpu" to /dev/dri/card1
	loading driver: amdgpu
(==) Matched amdgpu as autoconfigured driver 0
(II) LoadModule: "amdgpu"
(II) Loading /usr/lib64/xorg/modules/drivers/amdgpu_drv.so
(II) Module amdgpu: vendor="X.Org Foundation"
(II) AMDGPU: Driver for AMD Radeon:
	All GPUs supported by the amdgpu kernel driver
(II) AMDGPU(0): Creating default Display subsection in Screen section
(==) AMDGPU(0): Depth 24, (--) framebuffer bpp 32

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Further reading
texts.text: Further reading

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are  tons  of ways to filter journald logs and one of the best resources for learning about all of them is the  journalctl man page . There's also a  helpful journalctl cheat sheet  on GitHub.
texts.text: There are  tons  of ways to filter journald logs and one of the best resources for learning about all of them is the  journalctl man page . There's also a  helpful journalctl cheat sheet  on GitHub.
